abstract.p: A gerotor pump, which is widely used in the automotive industry for engine oil lubrication, produces an instantaneous flow fluctuation and the estimation of this is fundamental in order to evaluate the pump quality for silent and smooth operation. The intricate aspects of the pumping process of a gerotor pump make computational fluid dynamics the appropriate tool for modelling and simulation to provide insights into its flow characteristics. Because the instantaneous flow is rather dependent on the teeth contact, a new boundary condition of a virtual wall was developed, which allows simulation of the teeth contact in the interteeth radial clearances. This new boundary condition is utilized in a three-dimensional model of the gerotor pump with mesh deformation and remeshing at every time step by means of a home-made ad-hoc code programmed by the present authors and named viscous wall cell. The code has been integrated into the computational fluid dynamics solver. The interteeth clearances are studied under the following different operating conditions (working pressures and rotational velocities): first, no contact points (no teeth contact is studied in order to prove that, even if the interteeth radial clearance is sufficiently small, the leakage cannot be negligible); second, all contact points (the ideal approach is considered with zero interteeth radial clearances used to model zero manufacturing tolerances); third, one contact point at different locations (the existence of manufacturing tolerances and the teeth contact approach make the pump’s operation and its pumping mechanism more realistic in the simulation). The numerical instantaneous flow is compared with the analytical instantaneous flow, with the instantaneous flow modelled by using the bond graph technique, and with the experimental determination of the flow ripple for a specific unit. The results obtained show the importance of simulating the teeth contact and prove to be an excellent estimation of the instantaneous flow behaviour to obtain the dynamic properties of a gerotor pump under more realistic conditions than its design.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A gerotor pump, as a positive-displacement machine, produces an instantaneous flow, the fluctuation of which is superimposed upon the mean flow rate, consequently resulting in an irregular flow. This flow ripple has a periodic waveform due to the cyclic nature of the pump operation and is mainly influenced by the pumping mechanism. The performance indices of the pump, such as the volumetric efficiency, are directly influenced by the flow ripple. Therefore, the teeth contact (metal-to-metal contact) and the interteeth clearances (the gaps between gears) turn out to have a substantial effect on the flow ripple because the pumping process is based on them.

The gerotor pump, which is a trochoidal-gear type of pump, is widely used in applications ranging from fuel transportation in internal-combustion engines to oil circulation in fluid power transmissions. In recent years, researchers have focused on increasing the ratio of the power to the size by reducing the size of the pump, together with a higher rotation velocity, more demanding specifications and shorter design cycles. These facts have made the use of computational fluid dynamics (CFD) grow into an appropriate tool for modelling and simulating the flow characteristics inside the pump as a cost-effective and valuable method to improve its performance indices. Moreover, CFD leads to more effective experimental work. In comparison with other approaches, CFD allows exact control of the boundary conditions and monitoring of the results with either high temporal resolution or high space resolution. On the other hand, it can only reflect the phenomena included in the mathematical formulation, and the simulation procedure has to be validated by comparison with well-established theoretical and experimental results.

A large amount of work has been undertaken in the past on the simulation of gear pumps. This work can be divided into three categories: the calculation method, internal flows and clearance models. However, while the literature covers the large amount of work obtained by using CFD, the lack of a gerotor pump study that deals with analytical analysis, CFD simulation and experimental validation is to be noted. Hence, there is less documented work on modelling and simulating the interteeth clearance and teeth contact and their important effects on the flow ripple and, consequently, on the pump performance indices; this is the aim of this paper.

With reference to the calculation method, an arbitrary Lagrangian–Eulerian (ALE) approach is used to compute the flow.1 In the usual Eulerian method, the mesh is steady and the Eulerian Navier–Stokes equations have to be solved, including the convective term. With a pure Lagrangian method, the mesh moves with the fluid particles and the convective term vanishes, but the mesh motion can be difficult to compute. In an ALE approach, an intermediate solution is adopted and the mesh is not steady but moves independently with the fluid particles, following its mean flow.

Voorde et al.2 used an ALE approach at a two-external-gear compressor, forming a structured mesh at each time step by solving a Laplace equation for a potential function with suitable boundary conditions. Strasser3 performed a simulation with an external gear pump for mixing purposes, deforming and remeshing the grid at each time step with a non-structured mesh. Houzeaux and Codina4 adopted quite a different method by taking advantage of the periodicity of the gear motion and constructed 10 meshes for each gearing period. The simulation was performed by interpolating the solutions for each time step to the next mesh. Of these three approaches, only the third method dealt correctly with the problem of the contact point between gears.

With reference to internal flows, Castilla et al.5 implemented an innovative method for the study of the turbulent flow in the suction chamber of a gear pump. The mesh was deformed and locally remeshed, the mesh being replaced after a predefined number of time steps in order to avoid large distortions. Only one contact point was simulated by the union of the gears with a wall. For a certain mesh, this wall linked the same two nodes and, thus, was deformed. All previous approaches dealt with two-dimensional (2D) simulations as a common feature.

Suresh Kumar and Manonmani6 carried out a three-dimensional (3D) transient simulation of the inlet components of a gerotor pump for engine lubrication with incompressible flow. CF design commercial software, a design-oriented CFD modelling code with a moving dynamic meshing capability, was used. However, the simulation details did not show any evidence of simulating the teeth contact as a boundary condition.

With reference to clearance models, Biernacki and Stryczek7 investigated the mechanism of induction of stresses and deformations in plastic cycloidal gears used in gerotor pumps by using the finite-element method and ABAQUS software. An extensive analysis and modelling of radial and axial interteeth clearances was carried out. Both clearances resulted in internal leakages in the pump and lower efficiency of the machine. As a result of the investigation, the researchers established that it is necessary to make sure that the deformations of the teeth and gears, as well as the radial and axial clearances resulting from them, are smaller than the extreme clearance values assumed for the particular size of gerotor pump.

Gamez-Montero and Codina8 presented a study of the intricate aspects of internal leakage in a trochoidal-gear pump in order to simulate a real representation of the instantaneous flow by using a 2D dynamic analysis with the bond graph technique. The investigation developed the mathematical models of four different internal leakage flows: leakage flow through the trochoidal profiles (interteeth radial clearance), leakage flow through the sides of the gears and the housing and cover (axial clearance), leakage flow through the sides of the gears and the housing direct to the oil sump and (axial clearance) and, finally, leakage flow through the gear thickness and the housing (radial clearance).

In the present work, a new approach was developed and applied. The main reason for this is that the intricate characteristic of the process of pumping of a gerotor pump leaves no other option but to work with a 3D model that simulates the teeth contact and the interteeth clearance. On the one hand, a simplification of 2D CFD simulation would not be representative of the fluid inside the pump and significant conclusions could not be obtained. On the other hand, with no contact points, leakage flow through the interteeth clearance will be excessive owing to the high working pressure and operating conditions, i.e. the low rotational velocity of the gear set. As a result, the instantaneous flow and volumetric efficiency will decrease unrealistically.
Subsequently, to cope with these issues, the following specific aims of the present work were set.

list-item.p: The first aim is to establish a numerical procedure for accurate computer simulations that can provide insights into the flow characteristics of the gerotor pump.

The final aim is to compare the numerical results of instantaneous flow from simulations with the analytical model, dynamic simulations and experimental results from previous work of the present authors.

sec.p: For these purposes the first goal was to carry out 3D modelling of a gerotor pump with commercial CFD software. The second goal was to develop a clearance numerical model based on writing a code which searches the interteeth clearance and establishes a new boundary condition (teeth contact) to predict a real representation of instantaneous flow. The third and last goal was to carry out an instantaneous flow analysis of the model by means of CFD.
The conclusions obtained show their importance and prove to be an excellent estimation of the instantaneous flow behaviour.

sec.title: Teeth contact and interteeth clearances in a gerotor pump
sec.p: Essentially, a trochoidal-gear gerotor-type pump consists of a pair of gears: an inner rotor with external teeth called the inner–external gear and an outer ring with internal teeth called the outer–internal gear as in Figure 1(a). The two gears are mated so that each tooth of the internal gear is always in sliding contact with a tooth of the external gear, i.e. teeth contact occurs; these points are known as contact points. The external gear has Z teeth, one tooth more than the internal gear.

caption.p: (a) Gear set, line of contact (without the loop in the area of the central point of the meshing) and inlet and outlet ports at the reference position; (b) teeth contact and interteeth clearance with the manufacturing tolerance.

sec.p: The process of pumping is carried out when the rotational movement is transmitted from the internal gear to the external gear, creating circulation of the increasing volume from the inlet to the outlet port of the pump. Each volume is a sealed pocket of fluid between two consecutive contact points.

The chamber area in Figure 1(a) is isolated between the contact points P1 and P2 (the teeth contact located in the outer teeth PS0 and PS1 respectively) in the maximum area zone. From this position, when the gear set rotates, the contact point P2 of the isolated chamber crosses the border ii of the porting plate towards the outlet port. Then, a restricted flow passage is formed in the chamber area and this is delimited by the contact point P2 and the border, where the flow is pumped out to the delivery. Eventually, the contact point P1 will cross the border ii; then the flow passage becomes unrestricted and the chamber area is completely exposed to the outlet zone. Analogous processes are applied to the borders fi, ia and fa and the corresponding contact points.

Both gears rotate in the same direction but at different speeds because of the relation between the teeth, with the internal gear being slightly faster than the external gear. The angular velocity ratio is (Z− 1)/Z.

With the presence of a manufacturing tolerance, the outer gear is not always in sliding contact with the inner gear. In order to model the tolerance, the internal diameter of the outer gear is increased and, consequently, the two trochoidal profiles do not share any contact point. Then, if we suppose that the centres of the gears remain fixed and that there is no teeth deformation, the inner gear has to rotate a few degrees in order to establish teeth contact with the outer gear. Consequently, interteeth clearances occur, as depicted in Figure 1(b). The interteeth clearance approach allows calculation of the minimum interteeth clearance history for a complete rotation of the outer gear. Finally, the leakage model uses the minimum interteeth clearance history to evaluate the leakage flow through the interteeth clearances owing to the pressure gradient between adjacent chambers and its relative motion. (More details have been given by Gamez-Montero and Codina.8)

sec.title: CFD simulation: description and details
sec.p: The simulations presented here were carried out with the commercial algorithm ANSYS FLUENT (TM) 12.0.16, which is based on the finite-volume method. The basis of this method and its formulation have been described in detail elsewhere.5,9

For the particular case where the momentum balance has to be solved, an additional term for pressure at the boundary has to be added. In the present case, the pressure-staggered option (PRESTO) was chosen since it has been reported to give better results for high pressure and velocity gradients.10,11 PRESTO is a generalization to an unstructured mesh of the procedure described by Patankar12 for structured meshes.

For the continuity equation solution (both diffusive and source terms are null), a linear interpolation of the velocity at the face of the cell-centred values can produce chequer boarding of the pressure.13 In order to avoid that, two strategies are used. First, the velocity is momentum weight averaged by using the coefficients obtained from discretization of the momentum equations.14 Second, a pressure–velocity coupling algorithm is needed. From the available algorithms, the pressure implicit splitting of operators (PISO) algorithm is highly recommended because of its documentation for unsteady skewed mesh simulations. PISO is a variation of the semi-implicit method for pressure-linked equations (SIMPLE) algorithm,10 in which the calculations are moved inside the solution stage of the pressure correction equation15 and then the pressure correction gradients are recalculated and used to correct the mass flux.16
The fluid characteristics obtained in the present analysis are Newtonian, isothermal and compressible with unsteady three-dimensional flow.

sec.title: The mesh
sec.p: The computational domain of the fluid is divided into three zones, as depicted in Figure 2. Because the three zones are extrudable geometries, the 2.5D meshing technique is used, which is essentially an extrusion of a 2D mesh along the normal axis of the dynamic zone. This technique requires less time than regular volumetric meshing for the equivalent volume. The zones of the inlet and outlet ports are hexahedral structured stationary meshes. The inter-profiles zone is located between the inner gear and the outer gear profiles. In order to mesh this region, the outer gear has to be scaled and, as a consequence, no contact between the inner gear and outer gear profiles is established (Figure 3(a)) and the mesh can be created. This zone is a triangular prism unstructured deforming mesh.

caption.p: Computational domain: 3D mesh and defined zones.
Teeth contact simulation by using the viscous wall-cell strategy: (a) Z interteeth clearances and no contact points; (b) 3D Z contact points and no interteeth clearances.

sec.p: The simulations were carried out with a dynamic mesh, which is deformed and locally reconstructed, allowing considerable mesh quality with a time step value that links the mesh quality to the computation time. The inner gear is rotated counterclockwise and, consequently, the outer gear rotates counterclockwise, albeit slightly more slowly with the angular velocity ratio (Z– 1)/Z. The mesh in the inter-profiles zone is deformed and, if needed, remeshed when a cell is too small, large or skewed. The deformation of the mesh is made by using the spring-based smoothing method, in which the edges are idealized as springs. The new position of node n is then calculated iteratively until it converges to a whole mesh condition over the sum of all nodes m connected to node n. If the results are insufficient, the grid is locally remeshed. The time step value adopted in the present simulations is a compromise between the mesh quality and the computation time. On the one hand, it is sufficiently small to avoid a highly deformed mesh before completion of a gearing cycle and, on the other hand, it is sufficiently large to attain a reasonable simulation time.

sec.title: A new boundary condition: tooth contact in the interteeth clearance
sec.p: On the basis of the aforementioned process of pumping in a gerotor pump, the theoretical analytical model of gearing establishes Z contact points.17 However, on the basis of the aforementioned computational domain of the fluid in a CFD simulation of a gerotor pump, no contact between the inner and the outer profiles is established (no contact points and Z interteeth clearances). Teeth contact could be ignored and assumed to result in a reduction in the flow rate in the case of a small pressure difference. However, in the case of a gerotor pump with a pressure jump (the working pressure can reach more than 10 MPa), the teeth contact cannot be ignored, not only because of the disagreement in mass balance, but also because of the flow rate and pressure fluctuations that determine fluid flow in the inlet and outlet ports. Consequently, none of these leads to a realistic CFD model of the pump.

The motivation of the modelling and simulation by means of the CFD of one contact point (Z– 1 interteeth clearances) at different locations is based on the fact that, when manufactured tolerances exist, on the assumptions that the centres of the gear remain fixed and that no teeth deformation occurs, a unique contact point ocurrs. Then leakage flow through the interteeth radial clearance of the trochoidal profiles appears where no solid–solid contact exists, owing to the pressure gradient between adjacent chambers and its relative motion. As a result, the volumetric capacity, the flow ripple and, subsequently, the volumetric efficiency of the pump are considerably affected.

As a first step, it can be considered that simulation of the solid–solid contact on the gear should be carried out by changing the characteristics of the zone that separates the two solids from ‘fluid‘; to ‘solid’; when the separation is less than a small defined value. However, obviously, the entire region that separates the two gears cannot be changed to a solid.

The present simulation is complex because the contact is either at Z points (theoretical or ideal model) or at one point (total leakage model), and the position of the contact changes. Moreover, the part of the gears that comes into contact also changes over time with the ratio of the angular velocity of the inner gear to that of the outer gear. As was presented by Castilla et al.,5 this problem can be solved by the union of the gears with a small wall for an external-gear pump. However, this strategy cannot be implemented in the case of a gerotor pump, mainly because of two factors. The first factor is that the simulation of Z contact points would have to link a wall with the corresponding 2Z contact points for both gears, where every new mesh and each wall will change its position. The second factor is that, owing to the intricate characteristic of the process of pumping, the simulation has to be carried out with a 3D model of the pump. Both factors involve a complex simulation of the contact and a high computational time cost.

A leakage model based on a new strategy developed and named viscous wall cell by the present authors is instead adopted to simulate teeth contact, i.e. the solid–solid contact point between trochoidal gears. The strategy involves, first, finding the Z interteeth radial clearances with the minimum size. For every time step, the wall cell that corresponds to the minimum distance between each pair of inner–outer gear teeth is searched through the mesh located at each interteeth radial clearance. Once it is located, it is labelled the contact wall cell. Finally, the model enforces a high viscosity to each contact wall cell and, as a result, a virtual wall is created as a solid–solid boundary condition.

The main contribution of the present work is this new boundary condition of a virtual wall that allows simulation of the teeth contact in the interteeth radial clearance. This new boundary condition is applied at every time step by means of a home-made ad-hoc code programmed in C++ by the present authors. The algorithm of the code has been integrated in the CFD solver as a user-defined function which it is not included in the ANSYS FLUENT standard version. The viscous wall-cell strategy is shown in Figure 3(b) and the pseudo-code of the algorithm is presented in Figure 4.

sec.title: Results and general discussion
sec.p: To address the influences of the teeth contact and the interteeth clearance, the instantaneous flow is investigated in this work for several operating conditions of the pump by simulating Z interteeth clearances (no contact points in order to prove that, even if the gap between gears is sufficiently small, the leakage cannot be negligible), zero interteeth clearances (all contact points as a theoretical approach with zero manufacturing tolerances), and Z–1 interteeth clearances (a unique contact point at different locations as a more realistic approach with manufacturing tolerances). sec.title: Analytical versus CFD simulation results
sec.p: The simulation of all contact points is the closest CFD simulation to an analytical approach. Then, first of all, the viscous wall-cell strategy is tested with an analytical approach establishing Z new boundary conditions of teeth contact. Figure 5 shows the results of CDF simulation and the analytical instantaneous flow by using GEROLAB.17 GEROLAB software is an integrated package system based on analytical modules capable of developing a theoretical design of a gear set for a gerotor pump based on its main performance indices, such as the irregularity flow index of the flow ripple.

caption.p: Instantaneous flow at the outlet port (a working pressure of 0 MPa) for an inner gear rotational velocity of 7.5 r/min (1 tooth/s). GEROLAB analytical results and laminar CFD results by simulating Z contact points are presented.

sec.p: Instantaneous flow from simulation of Z contact points shows the characteristic double peak for an odd teeth number of the outer gear, presenting very good agreement with the analytical model. The simulation result is almost 0.2% higher than the analytical result that corresponds to it and (as a consequence) to the scaling of the outer gear, as can be seen in Figure 3. The irregularity flow index, defined as the ratio of the difference between the maximum and the minimum volumes to the averaged volume, is 2.8% in the analytical model and 2.5% in the Z-contact-points simulation. The difference arises also because the analytical model does not take into account the fluid compressibility.

sec.title: Results for no contact points, one contact point and all contact points
sec.p: Teeth contact between the inner and the outer gears, in the inner-profile zone, could be ignored because there are no simulating contact points and because it is assumed to result in a reduction in the flow rate in the case of small pressure differences. Nevertheless, even for a pressure jump of 0 MPa, the influence of the teeth contact cannot be ignored, not only because of the disagreement in the mass balance, but also because of the flow rate and pressure fluctuations that determine fluid flow in the inlet and outlet chambers.

Figure 6 depicts the influence of the teeth contact under the operation conditions in instantaneous flow. At 0 MPa, the no-contact-points simulation results in a reduction in the flow rate of 1% compared with that for the Z-contact-points simulation. However, at 0.5 MPa, the no-contact-points simulation results in a reduction in the flow rate of over 8% compared with that of the Z-contact-points simulation. Moreover, the 0 MPa no-contact-points contour of the instantaneous flow is clearly distorted. The influences of no contact points and Z contact points at 0 MPa are manifested in the reduction of almost 2% in the peak values, which can be justified by the compressibility effects when all contact points are simulated.

caption.p: Instantaneous flow at the outlet port for inner gear rotational velocities of 472 r/min and 2016 r/min. Laminar CFD results by simulating no contact points and Z contact points with working pressures of 0 MPa, 0.5 MPa, 1 MPa and 2 MPa are presented.

sec.p: However, the most significant influence of the teeth contact simulation can be observed in two main effects: the rotational velocity and the working pressure. At low rotational velocities (e.g. 472 r/min) and 0.5 MPa, when no contact points are simulated, the instantaneous flow and hence the volumetric efficiency are reduced by approximately 30% compared with those for the Z-contact-points simulation. However, at 2016 r/min and 0.5 MPa, it is reduced by approximately 10%, proving that the fluid adheres to the gears and is dragged, following their relative motion. The effect of the working pressure is also clearly shown by the no-contact-points simulation results because the volumetric efficiency is strongly reduced, falling for instance to 83% in the 2016 r/min, 1 MPa simulation. As a consequence, the influence of the teeth contact proves to be significant and it is proved that the viscous wall-cell strategy establishes a more realistic leakage flow model in the interteeth clearances.

A fluctuation characteristic can be observed in the results. When the first contact point that sealed the space of each chamber crosses the border of the beginning of the outlet zone ii, a high-pressure volume of oil from the outlet zone comes into the chamber. Owing to the existence of teeth contact between the inner and the outer profile teeth, the volume of the chamber is compressed and this effect is interpreted as a flow ripple through the bulk modulus.

Figures 7 and 8 show the influence of the teeth contact between the outlet port and the inlet port respectively. In this case, all-contact-points instantaneous flow is compared with a unique contact point. First, all-contact-points instantaneous flow was studied by using the bond graph technique. The bond graph models the volume of a generic chamber with compressibility effects. A modulated bond graph component includes the history of the interteeth radial clearance for a complete rotation of the outer gear. At the next level, Z chambers are assembled together and connected to the common sources: the flow source of the angular velocity of the shaft and the effort sources of the inlet and outlet zones. (More details have been given by Gamez-Montero and Codina.8)

caption.p: Instantaneous flow at the outlet port for an inner gear rotational velocity of 2016 r/min and a working pressure of 0.5 MPa. Bond graph ideal and with leakage flow through the trochoidal profiles (Qf,pt) instantaneous flow results and laminar CFD results by simulating teeth contact at the PS4 outer gear tooth and Z contact points are presented

Instantaneous flow at the inlet port for an inner gear rotational velocity of 2016 r/min and a working pressure of 0.5 MPa. Bond graph ideal instantaneous flow results and laminar CFD results by simulating teeth contact at the PS0 and PS5 outer gear tooth and Z contact points are presented

sec.p: The bond graph simulated instantaneous flow results for ideal flow (no leakage) and leakage through the trochoidal profiles (Qf,pt). The influence of the leakage is indicated by the reduction in the main peak. This phenomenon has the same explanation as before. A high-pressure volume of oil from the outlet zone comes into the chamber through the interteeth clearance passageway and the leakage phenomenon appears. The volume of the chamber is now less compressed and this effect is translated as flow ripple fluctuations because of the fluid compressibility. The same argument can be used with the minimum value when the chamber reaches the inlet zone.

Figures 7 and 8 also prove the influence of the teeth contact in the instantaneous flow. Two main contact point locations are considered: the contact points located at the PS4 and PS5 outer gear teeth (see Figure 1). These two locations are claimed to be the most representative contact points of the instantaneous flow because, based on the angular position of the gear set, the high-pressure zone (outlet port) and the low-pressure zone (inlet port) are separated by one of them. The contact point is located between the borders ia and fi of the porting plate. An analogous argument is applied to the contact point located at the PS0 outer gear tooth.

The contact point located at PS4 appears to have a longer distance between the end delivery and the start inlet borders. Therefore, a larger reduction of around 1.4% in the flow rate appears for PS4 than for PS5, and the shape of the instantaneous flow matches the Z contact points and bond graph simulation better.

Figure 9 shows the vectors of the velocity magnitude for 0.55t/Tg. The magnitude of the velocity becomes 20 times higher at the moment that the contact point crosses the ii border, as shown by the dotted circle.

Figure 10 shows that turbulent simulation does not give new information compared with laminar simulation, with a difference in the flow rates of 0.01%. Eventually, the flow may be locally turbulent owing to the shear flow near the contact points at the instant that the chamber opens to the outlet and inlet ports.

sec.p: However, this local increment in the turbulent flow does not seem to influence the shape of the instantaneous flow. As mentioned, the Reynolds number based on the hydraulic diameter indicated laminar flow in the ports and the chambers.

sec.title: Grid independence study
sec.p: A grid independence study was carried out to obtain the mesh convergence. The details of the grid independence study are provided in Table 4 where it is shown that the error in the mean normalized flow is 0.17% for the laminar model and 0.12% for the turbulent model. Considering this minimum error (Figure 11) and the performance of the central processing unit, the simulations presented here were performed with a mesh of about 600,000 cells and where the Courant number (the dimensionless number based on the time step, velocity and average cell size) is always less than 0.5.

sec.title: Flow ripple: simulation and experimental results
sec.p: A comparison between the simulation and the experimental results was also carried out. The flow ripple is calculated by extracting the averaged value 〈Qi〉 of the instantaneous flow from the instantaneous flow Qi and then normalizing it with the theoretical flow rate Qt.

The flow ripple from bond graph simulation obtained by taking into account the total leakage flows in the gerotor pump is presented in Figure 12. Figure 12 also depicts the experimental flow ripple obtained by using the secondary-source method and the test rig at the Laboratorio de Sistemas Oleohidráulicos y Neumáticos, Universitat Politecnica de Catalunya, in a real pump. The method is based on the measurement and frequency domain analysis of pressure standing waves in a pipe and uses a secondary source of pressure ripple for excitation of the pump under test. Using this information, it then becomes possible to evaluate the source flow ripple by measurement of the pressure ripple from the test pump. (More details have been given by Gamez-Montero and Codina.8)

caption.p: Flow ripple at the outlet port for an inner gear rotational velocity of 2016 r/min and a working pressure of 0.5 MPa. Laminar CFD results by simulating teeth contact at the PS5 outer gear tooth and experimental results are presented

sec.p: It has to be mentioned, however, that experiments and CFD simulations cannot be compared directly, since there is a fundamental difference; only the leakage flow through the trochoidal profiles is simulated and the more realistic flow has more leakage flow. This is the main reason that the experimental flow ripple has a small irregularity flow index.

Also, the CFD simulations use several simplifications that make the flow ripple move away from the real performance of the gerotor pump; for instance, the centres of the gear remain fixed. This also applies to bond graph simulation; even though it includes the leakage flow and despite its appearance as a good model, it cannot simulate the real performance of the pump.

In spite of this, the experimental results on the flow ripple show good qualitative agreement with the CFD simulation. The phenomenon of the contact point crossing the border between the inlet and outlet zones is simulated. The locations of the contact point at the PS4 and PS5 outer gear teeth provide the difference between the maximum and minimum peaks based on the gearing period, because of the corresponding angular positions. The agreement between the shapes of the flow ripple obtained from CFD simulation and from the measured results is shown to be good.

With regard to the mean flow rate, a difference can be observed between the simulation and the measurement results. The CFD simulation indicates a greater mean flow than do the experimental results. Taking into account the simplifications of the simulation model, namely that leakage-simulated flows are considered and that the centres of the gears remain fixed, the value of the mean flow shows good correlation and can be used at least for a qualitative study.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A complete study of the influence of the teeth contact and interteeth clearances in the flow ripple of a gerotor pump is documented in this paper. The three main goals of this work were achieved: a numerical procedure for accurate computer simulation of insights into the flow characteristics, simulation results under different pump operation conditions because of the manufacturing tolerances and its pumping mechanism owing to the teeth contact, and a qualitative and quantitave comparison of the analytical, dynamic and experimental results for a gerotor pump.

The main contribution of the present work is a leakage model in the three-dimensional CFD simulation which establishes a new boundary condition of a virtual wall that allows simulation of the teeth contact in the interteeth radial clearance. This model is based on a home-made ad-hoc code programmed in C++ by the present authors and named the viscous wall-cell strategy.

As methodological conclusions, the CFD and analytical model results show very good agreement with an irregularity flow index difference of 0.3%, validating the viscous wall-cell methodology. The no-contact-points simulation results show that the instantaneous flow is reduced and its shape is distorted. Then, an unrealistic drop in the volumetric efficiency proves that, even if the gap between gears is sufficiently small, the leakage cannot be negligible. The rotating velocity and the working pressure have important effects on the instantaneous flow. One-contact-point simulation also reduces the instantaneous flow. However, the location of the contact point simulation, when it crosses the borders of the porting plate, is captured in its quantitative shape. Hence, it was proved that the viscous wall-cell strategy establishes a more realistic leakage flow model with the relative velocity and pressure gradient through the interteeth clearances.

The simulated flow ripple disagrees with the experimentally measured results. This is attributed to the experimental measurements on a real pump and the simplifications made in the CFD model, namely the leakage flow through the trochoidal profiles and the fact that the the centres of the gears remain fixed. However, the flow ripple from simulation and measurement show good qualitative agreement, describing the main performance characteristics of a gerotor pump.

As design and technical conclusions, the viscous wall-cell approach may represent a useful tool for arriving at a deeper insight into the gerotor pump performance and, above all, for effectively validating the analytical and simulation models. Owing to the existence of the teeth contact and interteeth clearances, the effect in the flow ripple of the high-pressure volume of oil from the outlet zone indicates the necessity for designing relief grooves in the geometry of the ports in the porting plate. The data set itself is valuable as a validation resource with which other simulations can be compared, and for which an experimentalist can compare and access quantities that are challenging to measure.
As a final conclusion, this new numerical procedure aims to lead the designer to a better design by improving the performance indices of a new gerotor pump project.

sec.title: Future work
sec.p: The current study has established that the flow ripple characteristics can be obtained by using simulation techniques. Qualitative agreement is shown, while quantitative agreement is obtained under certain considerations. Future work will focus on taking into account the design of new relief grooves in the transition regions located in the borders of the porting plate of the inner and outer ports. These relief grooves should reduce the high peak pressure and oscillation that appears when the chamber opens to mainly the outlet port.

A desirable new approach would also take into account the leakage flow through the sides of the gears and radial clearances, and a great challenge would be the translation of the rotation centre of the gears, owing to the pressure distribution and solid contact.
